Description: Terracotta cooking stove fragment. A pot-support: a theatre mask of Dionysos, wreathed with ivy, with a very long and striated expanding beard; it is set within a rectangular panel, with a lintel-like strip above the head, with blurred architectural decoration. The back is plain but rough; only part of the everted rim survives. The support and panel were made in a onepiece mould. Very micaceous brown Nile silt with a red and grey core. There are signs of burning on the end of the beard.
Curator's comments: Two examples from Naukratis probably from the same mould series (British Museum 1886,1005.8; 1976,0102.4). Published (Walters 1903: C 873; Şahin 2001: 120, fig. 113:Na 5). This piece 'is close to Terracotta 3677: if the latter is an import to Egypt, then this piece was copied in Egypt from a stove from the same source' (Bailey 2008, no.3678). Şahin, M. 2001. Hellenistic braziers in the British Museum: Trade contacts between ancient Mediterranean cities. Anatolian Studies 51: 91-132.
